caption:
Friends actors Jennifer Aniston and David Schwimmer have paid their first tributes to co-star Matthew Perry following his death last month.
 
Schwimmer, who played Ross, shared a picture on Instagram of himself alongside Perry as Chandler.
 
"Thanks you for ten incredible years of laughter and creativity," he wrote.
 
Aniston, who played Rachel, posted a clip of her and Perry from the sitcom and wrote that she‚Äôd been ‚Äúpouring over‚Äù their texts that‚Äôs made her laugh and cry.
 
Perry, 54, was found unresponsive in a hot tub at his Los Angeles home at the end of October.
 
Tap the link in @BBCNews‚Äôs bio to read what Perry's other co-stars said about him in their tributes.
 
(üì∏ Getty)
 
#Friends #JenniferAniston #DavidSchwimmer #MatthewPerry #BBCNews

A BBC correspondent was reporting in Iceland when an immediate evacuation order came.
¬†
Residents were being allowed back into Grindavik in small numbers to quickly retrieve belongings when authorities ordered people to leave.¬†
¬†
A volcanic eruption is expected in the area, according to scientists.
¬†
Tap the link in @BBCNews‚Äôs bio to find out what the impact of an eruption could be.
¬†
#Iceland #Volcano #BBCNews

What‚Äôs it like for people breathing in Delhi‚Äôs toxic air?

On Monday, the morning after Diwali festival, when revellers burst firecrackers despite a ban, Delhi was among the world's top cities for pollution.

But pollution is also a year-round problem here, due to factors like high vehicular and industrial emissions and dust.

Tap the link in our bio to find out about what solutions there could be.

#Delhi #AirQuality #Pollution #BBCNews

The UK's highest court has ruled a government plan to deport asylum seekers to Rwanda is unlawful. 
 
The government had said its plan to deport asylum seekers to east Africa and ban them from returning was needed to deter illegal small boat crossings. 
 
But the Supreme Court ruled it was possible the Rwandan government would send people back to the country they had fled in the first place. 
 
It said the policy breaches human rights laws by potentially leaving the people sent there open to that risk.
 
UK PM Rishi Sunak said it was "not the outcome we wanted" and the government would "now consider next steps".
 
Tap the link in @BBCNews‚Äôs bio for reaction to the ruling. 
 
(üì∑ Reuters)
 
#UK #Rwanda #BBCNews

Israeli forces have entered Gaza's largest hospital in what the military says is a "targeted" operation. 
 
A journalist inside the Al-Shifa hospital told the BBC that Israeli soldiers are going room to room and interrogating people, but there is currently no shooting taking place. 
 
The same witness said commando soldiers had entered the main emergency department, with tanks also in the hospital area. 
 
Israel accuses Hamas of running a command centre in tunnels under the hospital and the US says it has intelligence that supports this. 
 
Hamas denies this and says the raid on the hospital is a war crime - hundreds of civilians have been sheltering there, alongside patients. 
 
Tap the link in @BBCNews‚Äôs bio for the latest developments. 
 
(üì∑ Reuters) 
 
#Gaza #Israel #BBCNews

Threads users can delete their account while keeping their linked Instagram account, under new changes.
 
An Instagram account is needed to sign up to the X-like app, formerly Twitter, but users were frustrated that it was impossible to delete Threads alone.
 
The platform said it had "heard feedback that you want more control over the experience", Instagram boss Adam Mosseri wrote.
 
The new feature will be accessible from the settings menu in a "Delete or Deactivate Profile" section.
 
Tap the link in @BBCNews‚Äôs bio to find out what other changes he announced.
 
(üì∏ Reuters/ EPA)
 
#Threads #Instagram #BBCNews

Friends stars Courteney Cox and Matt LeBlanc have paid their individual tributes to co-star Mathew Perry, following his death last month.
 
Cox, who played his on-screen wife Monica, shared a clip of her with Perry's character Chandler on Instagram and said she was "so grateful for every moment" they worked together.
 
Matt LeBlanc, who played roommate Joey, wrote, "It was an honour to call you my friend".
 
He added that: "It is with a heavy heart I say goodbye. I'll never forget you."
 
Perry was found dead at his Los Angeles home last month at the age of 54, sparking an outpouring of grief from fans across the world.
 
Cox also revealed that her character's marriage to Chandler was not the writers' original plan.
 
Tap the link in @BBCNews‚Äôs bio to find out what was.
 
#Friends #MathewPerry #CourteneyCox #MattLeBlanc #BBCNews

"We cannot change the past; however, this decision provides the Army and the American people an opportunity to learn from this difficult moment in our history."
 
The US Army has overturned convictions of 110 black soldiers who were arrested after the 1917 Houston Riots.
 
A military review found the soldiers were not given fair trials and were "wrongly treated" because of their race.
 
The riots took place after months of racial provocations against members of a regiment known as "Buffalo Soldiers".
 
Amid rumours of additional threats from a white mob, a group of armed black soldiers assembled in the Texas city, where clashes erupted.
 
The army convicted 110 soldiers from the regiment and ultimately nineteen were executed, while others were sentenced to life behind bars.
 
It remains the largest mass execution of American soldiers by the US Army.
 
Tap the link in @BBCNews‚Äôs bio to find out what will be done to characterise the soldiers‚Äô military service as honourable.
 
üì∑Houston Chronicle/Hearst Newspapers via Getty Images / Contributor
 
#BuffaloSoldiers #BBCNews

‚ÄúThe holy grail of postage".
 
A rare postage stamp has sold for $2m (¬£1.63m) in a New York auction, setting the record for the most expensive single US stamp sold.
 
The famous red, white and blue "Inverted Jenny" stamp dates back to 1918, and originally cost 24 cents.
 
Charles Hack, 74, made the monumental purchase on Wednesday, adding to his existing Jenny stamp collection.
 
Tap the link in @bbcnews‚Äôs bio to find out what makes the stamp so valuable. 
 
(üì∑ Siegel Auctions)
 
#Stamp #StampCollection #BBCNews

More than 1,000 people have been evacuated from an Icelandic town after 500 earthquakes hit the region on Monday, with fears a volcanic eruption could follow.

Tap the link in @bbcnews‚Äôs bio to read how the country plans to protect a power plant from possible lava flows.

#Iceland #Volcano #BBCNews

"The tyres were smoking."
 
A bystander managed to capture the moment a plane crashed into a car after it missed the runway at a Texas airport.
 
Luckily, the passengers of the plane were unharmed, while the car's driver sustained minor injuries.
 
Tap the link in @BBCNews's bio to see what else the bystander said he saw before the crash.
 
#Plane #Texas #BBCNews

Colombian footballer Luis D√≠az has been reunited with his father who was released after being kidnapped.
 
Luis Manuel D√≠az was released by rebels last week after being held hostage for 12 days.
 
The Liverpool striker and his father cried as they hugged each other for the first time after the abduction.
 
Luis Manuel D√≠az and his wife were kidnapped by the National Liberation Army (ELN), which sparked outrage in Colombia and abroad.
 
Tap the link in @bbcnews‚Äôs bio to hear what the rebels said about the "mistake" abduction.
 
(üì∑ Selecci√≥n Colombia)
 
#LuisDiaz #Colombia #BBCNews

‚ÄúSperm whales that call our sea home are prized citizens of Dominica.‚Äù

The Caribbean island of Dominica says it will create the world's first sperm whale reserve.
 
Commercial fishing and large ships would be banned in an area off the island's western coast measuring almost 800 sq km (300 sq miles), Prime Minister Roosevelt Skerrit said.
 
The area is a key nursing and feeding ground for the endangered mammals.
 
Mr Skerrit said the government wanted to make sure the ‚Äúprized‚Äù whales were safe from harm.
 
Tap the link in our bio to find out about new laws for tourists wanting to see the whales.
 
(üì∑ Getty)
 
#SpermWhale #Whales #Dominica #BBCNews

‚ÄúNo-one‚Äôs accountable, not at all, for anything.‚Äù
¬†
Leo was 15 when he first rented a Deliveroo account.
¬†
Two years later he was killed on a borrowed motorbike - still working for the app in the UK.
¬†
We‚Äôve found a black-market trade in delivery apps allowing underage teenagers to sign up as riders.
¬†
Tap the link in @BBCNews‚Äôs bio to read more about our investigation.
¬†
#Deliveroo #BBCNews

Dogs across Nepal have been celebrated for a day with flower garlands, bright paint and food.

The celebrations were part of the five-day Nepalese Hindu festival, Tihar.

Kukur Tihar, known as "day of the dogs", is the second day of the festival on which dogs are celebrated and appreciated for their loyalty and companionship to humans.
Hindus believe that the dog is the messenger of Yamaraj - the God of death.

The festival, which shares some traditions with Diwali in India, also celebrates cows and crows.

Tap the link in @bbcnews‚Äôs bio to see more pictures from this year‚Äôs Diwali celebrations. 
 
(üì∑ Getty/ EPA)
 
#Tihar #Nepal #BBCNews

"It's confusing, it's infuriating, it is censorship."
 
Pink will give away 2,000 free copies of books that have been "banned" by some schools in Florida to fans at her concerts in Miami this week.
 
The singer has waded into the row over some libraries and classrooms removing books with themes of sexuality, gender identity and race.
 
Florida authorities said they want to restrict inappropriate and harmful material but that they don't ban books.
 
Tap the link in @bbcnews‚Äôs bio to find out which books will be handed out at the concerts.
 
(üì∑ Getty)
 
#BBCNews

Nepalese officials have said TikTok‚Äôs content was ‚Äúdetrimental to social harmony‚Äù.
 
The decision to ban TikTok comes days after the country introduced a new rule requiring social media firms to set up liaison offices in the country.
 
Minister for Communications and Information Technology Rekha Sharma said that the platform spreads malicious content.
 
But Gagan Thapa, a senior leader of Nepali Congress, which is part of the coalition government, said officials should focus on regulating the platform.
 
Tap the link in our bio to find out which other nations have banned the platform.
 
(üì∑ PA)
 
#TikTok #BBCNews

A pilot has captured Aurora Borealis while flying from San Francisco to Lisbon.
 
Head to @BBCNews's bio to see pictures of the Northern Lights captured in the UK. 
 
#AuroraBorealis #SanFrancisco #Lisbon #Flight #BBCNews

Greta Thunberg was interrupted by a man who grabbed her microphone during a protest in Amsterdam.
¬†
The man climbed up on stage after Ms Thunberg invited Palestinian and Afghan women to speak on Sunday.
¬†
The man said he came for a ‚Äúclimate demonstration, not a political view‚Äù, after pro-Palestinian chants were heard from the crowd.
¬†
Tap the link in @bbcnews‚Äôs bio to read more about what unfolded at the climate change protest.
¬†
#ClimateChange #Climate #GretaThunberg #BBCNews

Kenya has a new national holiday. üå≥

Each year on 13 November, Kenyans will come together to plant trees in a bid to tackle climate change.

The holiday is part of the government's goal to plant 15 billion trees in 10 years, and allows "each and every Kenyan to own the initiative", according to Environment Minister Soipan Tuya.

The government is making available about 150 million seedlings in public nurseries, with Kenyans being encouraged to plant at least two each in order to reach the 100-million target.

Head to @bbcnews‚Äôs bio to see how the country will monitor the planting.

(üì∑ Getty)

#Seedlings #BBCNews

A state of emergency has been declared over an expected volcanic eruption in Iceland. 

Cracks have emerged on town roads as the small quakes have caused the landscape to shift.
 
Head to @BBCNews‚Äôs bio for the latest. 
 
#BBCNews

Millions of people have been celebrating one of the most important festivals in India, Diwali. üéÜ

The Hindu festival of lights celebrates the triumph of good over evil, and is marked with prayer, festive meals and fireworks.

People also light up their homes with small oil lamps called diyas and paper lanterns to signal the victory of light over darkness and joy over sadness.

Tap the link in our bio to find out why the annual celebrations have sparked air pollution concerns.

(üì∑ EPA/ Getty)

#Diwali #BBCNews

Al-Shifa hospital in Gaza City has ceased to function and the situation inside is ‚Äúdire and perilous", according to the World Health Organisation.
¬†
Streets surrounding the hospital are engulfed by fighting between Hamas and Israeli forces.

The newborns are being kept in a surgical theatre at the site. Surviving babies were at serious risk of death, according to doctors.
¬†
Staff said that three of 39 infants in their care died over the weekend due to there being no incubators.

Aid organisation Medical Aid for Palestinians has said¬†the dozens of newborn babies currently being treated at Gaza‚Äôs main hospital cannot be moved safely.

¬†It added the movement of critically ill newborns was a "complex and technical process".

The Israeli military has reiterated it is "ready to help" evacuate the dozens of newborn babies being cared for at the site to another hospital.
¬†
However, that evacuation is yet to happen as of Monday afternoon.

Israel has accused Hamas of having a command and control centre under the hospital - which the facility and Hamas deny.
¬†
Tap the link in our bio to read about Gaza‚Äôs hospitals caught on the front line of war.

(üì∑ Reuters)

#Gaza #Israel #BBCNews

Residents of India‚Äôs capital city Delhi woke up to skies looking like this.
 
The thick haze comes as the air quality dropped after the festival of Diwali, the Hindu festival of light.
 
People in the city burst crackers late into Sunday night despite a ban on fireworks due to high pollution levels.
 
Diwali, one of the most important festivals in the country, has been celebrated by millions across India.
 
People celebrate with prayer, enjoying festive meals and lighting fireworks; sweets are also distributed among neighbours and friends.
 
Tap the link in our bio to find out about what‚Äôs behind Delhi‚Äôs pollution around the year.
 
(üì∑ Getty)

#Delhi #BBCNews

Iceland is bracing for a volcanic eruption after experiencing hundreds of earthquakes.
 
More than 500 quakes have hit the Reykjanes Peninsula in the south-west of the country since midnight.
 
Experts have warned that there is a 15km-long (9 mile) river of magma running under the peninsula, threatening the now-evacuated town of Grindav√≠k.
 
The country has declared a state of emergency, while the Icelandic Meteorological Office has said there is considerable risk of an eruption.
 
University of Iceland professor of volcanology Thor Thordason warned: "We're talking about an imminent eruption unfortunately."
 
Meanwhile, the Blue Lagoon - one of Iceland‚Äôs most famous attractions - is also closed out of concern for employees' welfare.
 
Tap the link in @bbcnews‚Äôs bio to watch the moment an earthquake hits Grindav√≠k. 
 
(üì∑ Reuters/Getty)
 
#Iceland #Volcano #Earthquake #BBCNews

Police in France put a cork in an attempted champagne heist. üçæ
 
Two lorries containing the costly sparkling wine were reported stolen near Reims in the heart of the country‚Äôs Champagne region on Saturday.
 
Officers were able to locate the vehicles, which were equipped with tracking devices, and gave chase on a motorway between Reims and Paris.
 
While the champagne was eventually retrieved, the thieves managed to make their escape.
 
According to Le Parisien newspaper, the lorries consisted of bottles of Mo√´t & Chandon, one of the most renowned brands of champagne. 

Each load was valued at ‚Ç¨300,000 (¬£261,000; $320,000). 
 
Tap the link in @bbcnews‚Äôs bio to find out how the thieves got away.
 
(üì∑ Getty)
 
#France #Champagne #BBCNews

Fidias Panayiotou has apologised after a video titled I Travelled Across Japan For Free riled locals - with some calling for him to be arrested.

An ice rescue instructor and his wife put on their skates to experience a rare ‚Äúice window‚Äù in Alaska‚Äôs Alpine lakes.

An iconic leather jacket worn by Michael Jackson in the 1980s has been bought for ¬£250,000 ($306,000).
 
The black and white leather jacket, worn by the late singer in a Pepsi advert, sold at a London auction.
 
The commercial was the first of a series the star did for the company.
 
He sang a version of his hit Billie Jean... but one of the adverts was remembered for another reason.
 
Tap the link in @BBCNew‚Äôs bio to find out how Michael Jackson injured himself when filming one of the adverts.

Happy Diwali ‚ú®
 
Diwali is a major festival celebrating the triumph of light over darkness and the start of new beginnings for millions of people of the Hindu, Sikh and Jain faiths.

#Diwali #BBCNews

"It was quite a revelation."
 
A man depicted on the album cover of Led Zeppelin IV has been discovered to be a 19th Century thatcher.
 
"I instantly recognised the man with the sticks - he's often called the stick man," said Brian Edwards, from the University of the West of England, who found the original picture when looking through a photograph album for other research.
 
Released in 1971, the Led Zeppelin IV album has sold more than 37 million copies worldwide and includes the huge hit Stairway to Heaven.
 
Brian's research has since uncovered the name of the man, where he was from - and even the identity of the photographer. 
 
Tap the link in @BBCNews's bio to find out more about the thatcher.
 
#LedZeppelin #BBCNews

Have you ever wondered if rats have imaginations? 
 
Scientists now think they can find their way through spaces by using their imagination, based on how a space looked before.
 
Tap the link in @BBCNews‚Äôs bio to find out more about the study.
 
#Rats #BBCNews

‚ÄúI‚Äôm really going to miss them.‚Äù
 
Washington DC‚Äôs National Zoo has said goodbye to its three giant pandas, which have been returned to China.
 
Mei Xiang, Xiao Qi Ji, and Tian Tian were loaded on to a special ‚Äúpanda express‚Äù cargo plane, and flown to Chengdu.
 
Giant pandas have been at the zoo for 23 years, and visitors flocked to see them in recent weeks to say goodbye.
 
Tap the link in @BBCNews‚Äôs bio to find out the role pandas play in US-China relations.
 
(üì∑ EPA, Getty)

#GiantPandas #Pandas #BBCNews

‚ÄúOur home is the street now. Everything was destroyed.‚Äù

The BBC has spent two weeks talking to several families from an area in Gaza hit by retaliatory strikes from Israel after the Hamas attacks of October 7th.

They spoke to both established residents as well as younger, ambitious newcomers, who told us how they had grabbed whatever they could from their homes, watched those homes explode in front of their eyes, and then dispersed around Gaza to an uncertain fate.¬†

From makeshift shelters and temporary homes across the strip, residents wanted to tell the story of the life and demise of a neighbourhood they loved.

Tap the link in @BBCNews's bio to read more of their stories.¬†

(üì∑ Nashwa Rezeq, Hana Hussen, Mohamed)

#Gaza #al-Zahra #BBCNews

This deer soared into the back of a truck, just as the owner was about to sell it.

The buyer had just pulled up saying he was interested, ‚Äúas long as the body is as nice as it looks in the pictures‚Äù.

The US used two F-15 aircrafts to launch a ‚Äòself-defence strike‚Äô in Maysulun in eastern Syria on 8 November.¬†
¬†

"It's blown my socks off!"
 
The Beatles have made Official Chart history.
 
The fab four have returned to Number 1 in the UK with their new single Now and Then.
 
It follows the release of the group‚Äôs "final song".
 
The track has been 45 years in the making - with the first bars written by John Lennon in 1978 and the song finally completed last year.
 
The track by John, Paul, George and Ringo is their landmark 18th UK chart-topper and their first in 54 years, since The Ballad of John and Yoko in 1969.
 
And you can keep in touch with all your News on the updated BBC News app. All the top stories, breaking news, live reporting, and the option to follow news topics that match your interests.

You could say Taylor Swift is having quite the era‚Ä¶ üé§
 
She has now broken a Grammys record with her nomination for song of the year.
 
The shortlisting of her hit Anti-Hero makes Swift the first songwriter to score seven nominations in the category - beating Paul McCartney and Lionel Richie who are tied with six each.
 
She is also nominated in the album and record of the year categories - alongside Olivia Rodrigo, Miley Cyrus and SZA.

Actor and musician Jared Leto has become the first person to legally scale the Empire State Building.

The 51-year-old climbed the New York landmark wearing a bright orange jumpsuit using a rope and harness.

He took on the challenge to promote the forthcoming world tour for his band Thirty Seconds To Mars.

This is the moment a new island was born after a volcanic eruption in Japan.

The father of Colombian-born Liverpool footballer Luis D√≠az has been released by the guerrillas who kidnapped him 13 days ago, police sources and local media have said.
¬†
He was abducted on 28 October in the family's hometown Barrancas, Colombia.
¬†
The footballer's mother was also seized, but was freed within hours.
¬†
Local media said Mr D√≠az would undergo a medical examination before being returned to his family.
¬†
They also quoted authorities as saying that he was in a good state of health, with no signs of mistreatment.

"We did it!!!!"
 
US actors are expected to resume work after their union, Sag-Aftra, agreed a tentative deal with Hollywood studios to end a four-month strike.
 
The shutdown - combined with a separate writers' strike - paralysed much of the entertainment industry and disrupted numerous major films and TV shows.
 
Actors have been calling for better pay and safeguards on the use of AI.
 
Zac Efron, who found out about the deal at the premiere of The Iron Claw, described it as "incredible".
 
Jamie Lee Curtis posted on Instagram that "perseverance pays off".
 
Tap the link in @BBCNews's bio to find out more about what was agreed between the union and the studios.

"I knew it was the wave of my life." üèÑüèº‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è
 
Australian surfer Laura Enever has set a world record for riding the largest wave ever paddled into by a woman.
 
The 31-year-old tamed the 43.6ft (13.3m) beast at a break nicknamed the Himalayas in Oahu, Hawaii.
 
It beat the previous record - which stood for seven years - by a foot.
 
Enever's feat was certified by Guinness World Records on Thursday at a ceremony in Narrabeen, Sydney - the suburb where she grew up and launched her career.
 
Tap the link in @BBCNews's bio to find out more about her other accolades in the sport.

A 1932 Pablo Picasso masterpiece has sold for $139m (¬£113m).

It is the second highest price ever achieved for the Spanish artist, according to auctioneers Sotheby‚Äôs.

Femme a la Montre (Woman with a Watch) is also the most valuable work sold at auction this year.

It was previously owned by the late art collector Emily Fisher Landau and has been bought by an anonymous buyer.

Tap the link in @BBCNews‚Äôs bio to find out who the woman depicted in the painting is.

(üì∑ PA)

#Picasso #BBCNews

A man has been crushed to death by a robot in after it failed to differentiate him from the boxes of food it was handling.
 
The incident occurred when the man was inspecting the robot at a plant in South Korea, according to reports.
 
The robotic arm confused the man for a box of vegetables and pushed his body against the conveyer belt, crushing his face and chest, South Korean news agency Yonhap said.
 
He had been checking the robot's sensor operations ahead of its test run at a pepper sorting plant.
 
The man was taken to hospital but later died.
 
Tap the link in @BBCNews's bio to see how the owners of the plant responded.

(Getty)
 
#Robotics #BBCNews

A legal complaint against Coca-Cola, Danone and Nestle has been issued by a consumer body and two environmental groups in Europe.
 
The complaint alleges the companies are misleading consumers into buying a product which is sold as being climate-friendly or sustainable, known as greenwashing, when it comes to their "100% recycled" claims on single-use plastic water bottles.
 
The European Consumer Organisation, backed by the environmental groups Client Earth and ECOS, claims the bottles are never made wholly of recycled materials.

They say the ability to recycle them depends on a number of factors, including the tools available.
 
Coca-Cola said its packaging messages can be substantiated, Nestl√© said it was cutting use of plastic packaging, and Danone said it was investing in recycling.
 
Tap the link in @BBCNews's bio to see what could happen to the companies if the complaint is upheld.
 
(üì∑ Getty, BEUC)
 
#CocaCola #Nestle #BBCNews

Producer and rapper Timbaland has apologised after being criticised for suggesting Justin Timberlake should "put a muzzle" on Britney Spears.
 
In her recent memoir, Spears revealed details about her relationship with Timberlake between 1999 and 2002.
 
Earlier this week, Timbaland said during an interview, "I wanted to call and say, 'JT you've got to put a muzzle on that girl, man'."
 
However, after significant social media backlash, he said: "I apologise to the Britney fans and her."
 
Tap the link in @BBCNews's bio to see what Britney's fans had to say about the comments.
 
(üì∑ Getty)
 
#Timbaland #BritneySpears #BBCNews

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt recall.‚Äù
¬†
Ivanka Trump claimed she could not remember property deals she handled at her father‚Äôs firm, as she testified in a civil fraud case that threatens his business empire.
¬†

A drug which could prevent breast cancer is to be offered to thousands of women in England.
 
Anastrozole, used for many years to treat breast cancer, has now been licensed as a preventative option after a successful trial in women.

An estimated 289,000 women could be eligible for the drug.
 
Charities said it was "a major step forward" for women with a significant family history of breast cancer.
 
Lesley-Ann Woodham is one of the women who recently took anastrozole as a preventative course and called the treatment "a gift".

"We are human, we want to understand everything around us."
 
Europe's Euclid telescope is ready to begin its quest to understand the greatest mysteries in the Universe.
 
Many telescopes have captured images of space, like The Horsehead gas cloud where stars are being born, but none with the width and sharpness that Euclid can.
 
Euclid will now survey a third of the sky over the next six years to gather clues about so-called dark matter and dark energy.
 
"We don't currently understand 95% of the Universe, a universe that is 13.8 billion years old."
 
Tap the link in @BBCNews's bio to read how Euclid was developed and how it will gather the data.

And you can keep in touch with all your News on the updated BBC News app.  All the top stories, breaking news, live reporting, and the option to follow news topics that match your interests.

Thousands of Afghans in Pakistan have made their way back to Afghanistan in the last two months ahead of the crackdown.
 
Many say they are terrified to be heading back to the Taliban government.

A devilish figure that disappeared from a celebrated and controversial 18th-Century painting has been rediscovered. üëπ
 
Sir Joshua Reynolds painted a demon lurking in the shadows in his picture The Death of Cardinal Beaufort, based on a Shakespearean death scene.
 
But "the fiend" eventually disappeared beneath layers of paint and varnish.
 
The 1789 artwork has now been restored and put back on display, with the demon in full view.
 
The fanged creature can be seen at the head of the bed, in the shadows, as Cardinal Beaufort lies dying, with King Henry VI and two lords at his bedside.
 
Tap the link in @BBCNews's bio to find out why the painting was so heavily criticised when it was first displayed.
 
(üì∑National Trust)

A new study has shown that cats have up to 276 different facial expressions - some of which they share with humans. üòº
 
Researchers at University of California in Los Angeles have been investigating the different types of facial expressions cats use to communicate with each other.

Humans have around 44 unique facial movements, but their total number of expressions isn't known, so it‚Äôs hard to compare cats with us - but we do know that chimpanzees have around 357 unique expressions. 
 
The team also found that cats have some expressions in common with humans - and think they may have picked them up from their 10,000 year history of living with us.
 
Tap the link in @BBCNews's bio to find out what some of them mean.
